text: To establish negligence, a plaintiff must prove four essential elements: (1) duty of care, (2) breach of that duty, (3) causation, and (4) damages. Each element must be proven by a preponderance of the evidence, meaning it is more likely than not that the defendant was negligent. The duty of care arises from the relationship between the parties and the foreseeability of harm.
title: Elements of Negligence

text: A breach of duty occurs when the defendant fails to exercise reasonable care. The standard is objective: what would a reasonable person do in similar circumstances? This is not based on the defendant's subjective beliefs or intentions. Factors considered include the likelihood of harm, the magnitude of potential harm, and the burden of taking precautions.
title: Breach of Duty Standard

text: Causation in negligence requires both actual cause (cause-in-fact) and proximate cause (legal cause). Actual cause is often determined using the but-for test: but for the defendant's conduct, would the harm have occurred? Proximate cause limits liability to foreseeable consequences and prevents liability for remote or unforeseeable harms.
title: Causation Requirements

text: Damages in negligence cases must be actual and quantifiable. The plaintiff cannot recover for nominal damages alone. Compensatory damages may include economic losses such as medical expenses and lost wages, as well as non-economic losses like pain and suffering. Punitive damages are rarely available in negligence cases.
title: Types of Damages

text: The duty of care is determined by the relationship between parties and the foreseeability of harm. In general, everyone owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing foreseeable harm to others. Special relationships may create heightened duties, such as common carriers to passengers or innkeepers to guests.
title: Duty of Care Principles

text: Res ipsa loquitur (the thing speaks for itself) is a doctrine that allows a plaintiff to establish a prima facie case of negligence through circumstantial evidence. It applies when: (1) the accident is of a type that ordinarily does not occur without negligence, (2) the instrumentality was under the defendant's exclusive control, and (3) the plaintiff did not contribute to the accident.
title: Res Ipsa Loquitur Doctrine

text: Negligence per se occurs when a defendant violates a statute or regulation designed to protect against the type of harm that occurred. In such cases, the violation establishes breach of duty. The plaintiff must show: (1) they are in the class of persons the statute was intended to protect, and (2) the harm is of the type the statute was designed to prevent.
title: Negligence Per Se

text: Comparative negligence is a defense that reduces a plaintiff's recovery based on their own degree of fault. In pure comparative negligence jurisdictions, a plaintiff can recover even if they are 99% at fault, though their recovery is reduced proportionally. In modified comparative negligence jurisdictions, a plaintiff cannot recover if they are more than 50% at fault.
title: Comparative Negligence Defense

text: Assumption of risk is a complete defense to negligence when a plaintiff voluntarily encounters a known risk. There are two types: express assumption of risk (through agreement) and implied assumption of risk (through conduct). The defendant must prove the plaintiff knew of the specific risk and voluntarily chose to encounter it.
title: Assumption of Risk

text: Professional negligence, or malpractice, occurs when a professional fails to exercise the degree of skill and care ordinarily expected of members of that profession in good standing. The standard is not perfection but rather the reasonable care expected of similarly situated professionals. Common examples include medical malpractice and legal malpractice.
title: Professional Negligence Standards
